questions.text: An industrial worker sustained burn injuries to the anterior region of his chest and abdomen, as well as burns to his right upper limb and a circumferential burn to his right thigh, as a result of a cylinder explosion. What is the percentage of total burned surface area?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

36 By Wallace rule of nine: 9%(anterior chest) + 9%(anterior abdomen) + 9% (right upper limb) + 9%circumferential right thigh ( 4.5% + 4.5%) = 36%

questions.text: If open cardiac massage were to be performed on a patient, what category would it come under?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contaminated Open cardiac massage is performed for inadequate cardiac output due to penetrating chest trauma, Cardiac tamponade etc. It leads to major break in the sterile protocols. Hence, classified as a contaminated wound.

Highyeild:

Surgical site infections must occur within 30 days of operative procedure if no implant is in place or within 1 year , if implant is in lace and the infection appears to be related to the surgical procedure They are classified based on the depth and tissue layers involved as superficial incisional , deep incisional and organ/space CDC classifies wound into four groups with progressively increasing risk of SSI as CLASSIFICATION DESCRIPTION I-Clean An uninfected operative wound in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tract is not entered. In addition, clean wounds are primarily closed and, if necessary, drained with closed drainage. Operative incisional wounds that follow no penetrating (blunt) trauma should be included in this category if they meet the criteria. II-Clean- contaminated An operative wound in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination. Specifically, operations involving the biliary tract, appendix, vagina, and oropharynx are included in this category, provided no evidence of infection or major break in technique is encountered. III-Contaminated Open, fresh, accidental wounds. In addition, operations with major breaks in sterile technique (e.g., open cardiac massage) or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, no purulent inflammation is encountered are included in this category. IV-Dirty-infected Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and those that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera. This definition suggests that the organisms causing postoperative infection were present in the operative field before the operation.

Extraedge:

CDC/NHSN CLASSIFICATION OF SURGICAL SITE INFECTIONS CLASSIFICATION DEFINITION Superficial incisional SSI (SIS) Infection occurs within 30 days after the operative procedure and involves only skin and subcutaneous tissue of the incision and had at least one of the following: a. Purulent drainage from the superficial incision. b. Organisms isolated from an aseptically obtained culture of fluid or tissue from the superficial incision. c. At least one of the following signs or symptons of infection: pain or tendeness, localized swelling, redness, or heat, and superficial incision is deliberately opened by surgeon and is culture positive or not cultured. A culture-negative finding does not meet this criterion. d. Diagnosis of superficial incisional SSI by the surgeon or attending physician. Deep incisional SSI (DIS) Infection occurs within 30 days after the operative procedure if no implant is left in place or within 1 year if implant is in place and the infection appears to be related to the operative procedure and involves deep soft tissues (eg, fascial and muscle layers) of the incision and patient has at least one of the following: a. Purulent drainage from the deep incision but not from organ/space component of the surgical site. b. Deep incision spontaneously dehisces or is deliberately opened by a surgeon and is culture-positive or not cultured when the patient has at least one of the following signs or symptoms: fever (>38°C) or localized pain or tenderness. A culture-negative finding does not meet this criterion. c. An abscess or other evidence of infection involving the deep incision is found on direct examination, during reoperation, or by histopathologic or radiologic examination. d. Diagnosis of a deep incisional SSI by a surgeon or attending physician. Wound that has both superficial and deep incisional infection is classified as DIS Organ/space SSI Infection occurs within 30 days after the operative procedure if no implant is left in place or within 1 year if implant is in place and the infection appears to be related to the operative procedure and infection involves any part of the body, excluding the skin incision, fascia, or muscle layers, that is opened or manipulated during the operative procedure and patient has at least one of the following a. Purulent drainage from a drain that is placed through a stab wound into the organ/space. b. Organisms isolated from an aseptically obtained culture of fluid or tissue in the organ/space c. An abscess or other evidence of infection involving the organ/space that is found on direct examination, during reoperation, or by histopathologic or radiologic examination. d. Diagnosis of an organ/space SSI by a surgeon or attending physician.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Specimens revealed that she had gall bladder carcinoma infiltrating the muscularis layer. What is the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extended cholecystectomy T1b - lesions which penetrate the muscularis layer but not deeper connective tissue or serosa In these case , extended cholecystectomy is the option as there are likelihood of increase in nodal disease with T1b lesions and perineural , lymphatic or vascular invasion

Highyeild:

Cases in which carcinoma is found after cholecystectomy , subsequent treatment depends on depth of penetration of gallbladder wall and surgical margins T1a - carcinoma penetrate lamina propria but do not invade muscle layer Treatment: cholecystectomy Cystic duct margin is resected sometimes to obtain negative margin T1b - lesions which penetrate the muscularis layer but not deeper connective tissue or serosa Extended cholecystectomy is done ( to avoid nodal disease ). It is directed at obtaining R0 resection of disease , including draining lymph node basins It involves removal of gallbladder , segments IV na V of liver and the lymph nodes along the hepatoduodenal ligament , either with or without removal of CBD T2 - cancer extending past the muscularis but not beyond serosa Similar approach like before with Radical cholecystectomy is indicated because more than 40% of these patients have lymph node metastasis and up to 25% have positive margins when treated with standard cholecystectomy alone presence of any residual disease , after operative intervention predicts poor outcome

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: B . Adjuvant chemotherapy ( Gemcitabine based regimens , combining with platinum agents often ,are typically used for treating gallbladder cancer. patient with high risk lesions ( T4 tumors , positive lymph nodes , R1 resection ) are considered for adjuvant therapy OPTION: D . Surveillance has no role as there is cancer after cholecystectomy and any delay in treatment could deteriorate the life of the patient

questions.text: In which of the following malignancies, a liver transplantation is not contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Testicular cancer Liver transplantation is not relatively contraindicated in testicular cancer

Highyeild:

Past history of malignancy is a relative contraindication to transplantation , because the effect of surgery and the consequent immunosuppression may predispose the patient to early recurrence of tumor Testicular carcinoma has low risk of recurrence ( 0 to 10 %) , while melanoma and symptomatic renal cancer has a risk of > 26% Breast cancer , recurrence rates are 33% , but based on effect of immunosuppression on tumor recurrence ( 10 -25%) In only exceptional cases , patients with any of extrahepatic malignancy ( such as colorectal carcinoma , oral squamous carcinoma , nonmelanoma skin cancer, vulvovaginal cancer , thyroid cancer , breast cancer) are considered as suitable candidates for transplantation

questions.text: A patient presented with a Type 1 Choledochal cyst. All of the following statements are correct, except?

options.label: D
options.text: Cyst opened and drainage is done.

questions.correct_answer: D. Cyst opened and drainage is done.
questions.explanation:

Cyst opened and drainage is done. Radical excision of the cyst is the treatment of choice with reconstruction of the biliary tract using Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum All the other options are correct statements

questions.text: A 63-year-old female presented to the OPD with abdominal pain and a tense and tender swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. What is the most likely diagnosis of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Strangulated femoral hernia Femoral hernia are below and lateral to the pubic tubercle & Inguinal hernia is above & medial to pubic tubercle. Signs of abdominal obstruction are suggestive of strangulation of the hernial components. Also, femoral hernia are more susceptible to obstruction & strangulation as the femoral ring cannot dilate.

Highyeild:

Femoral hernia are less common than inguinal hernia and are more common in women than in men Female pelvis has a different shape from male, increasing size of femoral canal and risk of hernia It appears below and lateral to pubic tubercle and lies in the upper leg rather than in the lower abdomen. Inadequate exposure leads to failure to detect hernia As it increases size , it is reflected superiorly and becomes difficult to distinguish from a medial direct hernia , which arises few cm above femoral canal Though no specific investigations are required , in emergencies , bowel obstruction is present and plain radiograph shows it CT scan is now done in bowel obstructions to exclude malignancy Surgery for femoral hernia Low approach ( Lockwood): simplest operation and is suitable only where no risk of bowel resection Inguinal approach ( Lotheissen) High approach (McEvedy): ideal in emergency situation ,where risk of bowel strangulation is high Henry procedure: repair of bilateral femoral hernia through single incision, the preperitoneal approach is extended to gain access to perform it Laparoscopic: TEP , TAPP - ideal for reducible femoral hernia presenting electively

questions.text: A man presented with a history of stab injury over the arm. On examination, there was a hematoma present, and radial and ulnar pulses were not felt. A 3.5cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which among the following is the best treatment option?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary repair with end to end anastomosis

options.label: B
options.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.correct_answer: B. Repair with great saphenous vein graft
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Repair with great saphenous vein graft In cases of management of brachial artery and femoral vessels injury , autogenous vein ( saphenous vein ) is used

Highyeild:

Penetrating injury of the upper extremity often presents with history of either arterial hemorrhage or bleeding Diagnosis is often made by the physical examination alone Absent pulses in the presence of complex fractures or crush injuries of the upper extremity need to be assessed with imaging , if normal perfusion does not return after resuscitation and the administration of adequate pain medications Saphenous vein is harvested from the uninjured leg Brachial artery is exposed through longitudinal incision along the medial aspect of upper arm over the groove between triceps and biceps muscles Proximal brachial arteries require control of infraclavicular arteries In repairing both venous and arterial injuries , vein should be repaired first and if the duration of arterial occlusion and ischemia are concern , temporary intraluminal shunts may be placed in artery Primary tension free repair remains as a second chance to autologous vein in the management of brachial artery and femoral vessels

Extraedge:

History and physical examination findings of vascular injury Hard Findings Indicate need for immediate intervention for vascular injury • Pulsatile bleeding • Expanding hematoma • Palpable thrill or audible bruit • Evidence of extremity ischemia • Pallor • Paresthesia • Paralysis • Pain • Pulselessness • Poikilothermia Soft Findings Consider further imaging and evaluation for vascular injury • History of moderate hemorrhage • Proximity fracture, dislocation, or penetrating wound • Diminished but palpable pulse • Level of peripheral nerve deficit in proximity to major vessel • Wounds in proximity to extremity or neck vessels in patients with unexplained hemorrhagic shock
